fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A reflexive pair is the categorical translation of a reflexive relation. It is defined as a pair of arrows \partial_0, \partial_1 : X \rightrightarrows Y with a common section r : Y \to X, i.e. an arrow r such that \partial_0 \mathbin{\circ} r = \partial_1 \mathbin{\circ} r = {\textrm{id}}_Y. A coequalizer of a reflexive pair is called a reflexive coequalizer.

Let G : {\mathcal{D}} \to {\mathcal{C}} be a functor with a left adjoint F. M = G \mathbin{\circ} F is the corresponding monad on {\mathcal{C}}. This gives a comparison functor K : {\mathcal{A}} \to {\mathcal{C}}^M.

fr:ol.fr:li: If {\mathcal{D}} has all coequalizers (we can weaken this to reflexive coequalizers), then K has a left adjoint.
If moreover G preserves these reflexive coequalizers, the unit {\textrm{Id}} \to K \mathbin{\circ} L is an isomorphism.
Finally, if G reflects isomorphisms, then the counit L \mathbin{\circ} K \to {\textrm{Id}} is also an isomorphism, making G monadic.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For the final point, we would like the coequalizer of FG\epsilon, \epsilon : FGFGX \rightrightarrows FGX to be isomorphic to X. If we apply G to the diagram, we get an isomorphism to GX by the previous point. So if G reflects isomorphisms, weâ€™re done.
